article.head: Adaptation progress
article.tag: Track how countries are building climate resilience

text.p: Even if all manmade greenhouse gas emissions stopped overnight, the impacts of climate change have already arrived. Now the world is asking, to what extent can we adapt? This is set to be one of the most important questions of the 21st century. Without adaptation, societies and economies may collapse, food security will be threatened, and global stability challenged as a result of migration and conflict over resources. Furthermore, the analyses are clear: investments in adaptation generate enormous social, environmental and economic benefits.
The UNEP Climate Action Note shows you the global state of climate action and where each country has work to do.

article.title: Adaptation finance gap

article.head: Annual adaptation finance needs for developing countries 2021-2030
article.attribution: The maps were produced using imagery by the NASA Earth Observations team using data courtesy of the MODIS Land Science team at NASA Goddard Space Flight Center.

text.p: Lack of finance is a major barrier to adapting to climate change in developing countries, for whom the combined costs of adaptation are now estimated to be between US$215 billion and US$387 billion per year. The priority sectors for adaptation vary by region. For example, in East Asia and the Pacific, the sector with the largest adaptation finance needs is infrastructure and settlement, while in Europe and Central Asia, it is the water sector.

article.title: National Adaptation Plans
article.head: National Adaptation Plans (NAPs) in developing countries

text.p: Developing countries are encouraged to submit their National Adaptation Plans (NAPs) to the NAP Central platform developed by the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Informed by the latest climate science, these plans are vital for identifying medium- and long-term adaptation needs. UNEP, currently supporting 23 countries in developing their NAPs, argues that they offer a crucial opportunity to upscale nature-based solutions, which have been gaining popularity in recent years.

article.title: Adaptation projects
article.head: How UNEP is supporting the race to resilience

text.p: UNEP has assisted more than 70 projects on climate change adaptation in over 50 countries. Combined, the projects are aiming to benefit around 3.5 million people, restore 241,000 hectares of land, improve climate adaptation knowledge of 323,000 people and 131 institutions, and build over 7,800 water harvesting structures and 82 weather stations.
